original_data.question: A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of a painless lump near the left wrist and tingling pain over his left hand. Physical examination shows a transilluminating, rubbery, fixed, non-tender mass over the lateral volar aspect of the left wrist. There is decreased sensation to pinprick on the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and radial half of the ring finger of the left hand. The tingling pain is aggravated by tapping over the swelling. Which of the following adjacent structures is at risk of entrapment if this mass persists?

model_response:
The tingling pain over the left hand is due to compression of the median nerve, and the mass is probably a ganglion cyst. The median nerve is in close proximity to the flexor pollicis longus tendon, which is at risk of entrapment if the mass persists. The ulnar artery is in close proximity to the flexor carpi radialis tendon, but this tendon is not at risk of entrapment. The ulnar nerve is in close proximity to the ulnar artery, but this nerve is not at risk of entrapment. The flexor carpi ulnaris tendon is in close proximity to the ulnar nerve, but this tendon is not at risk of entrapment.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Not causing physical or psychological misery, pain or distress.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Situated at or extending to the side.
A subjective response indicating that something is or has decreased.

The process in which specialized SENSORY RECEPTOR CELLS transduce peripheral stimuli (physical or chemical) into NERVE IMPULSES which are then transmitted to the various sensory centers in the CENTRAL NERVOUS SYSTEM.
The second finger from the radial side of the hand, next to the thumb.
The middle or third finger from the radial side of the hand.
Arranged like rays or radii; radiating from a common center or moving in the direction of a radius; relating to or near the radius.
The fourth finger from the radial side of the hand.

An invasive procedure in which a hollow needle is introduced through an intervertebral space in the lower back to access the subarachnoid space in order to sample cerebrospinal fluid or to administer medication.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in TISSUES or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the SKIN in SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE.
The probability that an event will occur. It encompasses a variety of measures of the probability of a generally unfavorable outcome.

Narrowing or stenosis of a tendon's retinacular sheath. It occurs most often in the hand or wrist but can also be found in the foot or ankle. The most common types are DE QUERVAIN DISEASE and TRIGGER FINGER DISORDER.
